awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Intelligent and Agile Robotic Legged Locomotion in Complex Environments: From Planning to Safety and Robust Control
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance the progress of science, national prosperity and welfare, by enhancing walking capabilities of robotic systems. While legged robots are becoming more mechanically sophisticated, their agility, dexterity, and dynamic stability are still far from capabilities of their biological counterparts (such as animals and humans) in real world situations. The overarching goal of this project is to create a formal foundation to enable intelligent and fast motion planning, safety, and robust control for a multitude of agile behaviors of autonomous legged machines in real-world situations. This research will have broad societal impact through seamless integration of control theory, optimization, and intelligence to enable ubiquitous use of increasingly sophisticated robots. Such robots will be able to effectively assist, or serve as remote extensions of, humans in situations of extreme danger, such as industrial accidents and natural disasters. The integrated educational plan will have broad impact by designing new courses. STEM-based outreach initiative for K-12 students, teachers, and under-represented minorities, and engagement of undergraduate students in research.

The project will advance knowledge in the largely unexplored field of intelligent and robust legged locomotion through key innovations in controls and analysis. Intelligent and fast motion planning algorithms, based on hybrid systems theory, optimization, and perception, will be created for dynamical models of legged locomotion in complex environments. The project will address the synthesis of robust-optimal controllers, based on nonlinear control and matrix inequalities, for agile and dexterous locomotion. It will also create safety-critical control algorithms, based on set invariance and quadratic programming, for real-world implementation of robust controllers that guarantee obstacle avoidance in unknown environments. To bridge the gap between theory and implementation, this research will transfer the theoretical innovations into practice through experiments with two advanced quadrupedal and bipedal robots in researchers' laboratories at Virginia Tech and Caltech sites.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
This work aimed to realize the goal of deploying intelligent and highly agile legged locomotion in real-world environments. Although legged robots are becoming more mechanically sophisticated and complex with higher degrees of freedom, there is a significant gap between the agility, dexterity, and dynamic stability demonstrated by the state-of-the-art legged machines and their biological counterparts in real-world situations. While the technology in constructing these machines is rapidly advancing, the pace of hardware innovations exceeds the ability of computational control algorithms. This work aimed to create a firm foundation, based on hybrid systems theory and scalable optimization algorithms, to enable intelligent planning, safety, and robust control for a multitude of agile behaviors of autonomous legged machines in real-world situations. This was a collaborative project between Virginia Tech and Caltech.

Intellectual Merit: Numerous innovations were developed in the context of this project: from nonlinear optimization-based low-level controllers, to the use of reduced-order models to realize diverse walking gaits, to data-driven methods for robust and adaptive legged locomotion.

First, this project developed a low-level nonlinear and robust controller for stabilizing legged locomotion—on bipeds, quadrupeds and lower-limb powered prostheses. This framework utilizes virtual constraints and control Lyapunov functions (CLFs) based quadratic programs (QPs), CLF-QPs, to robustly stabilize periodic orbits for hybrid system models of legged robots. Theoretically, properties of the CLF-QP were studied, wherein sufficient conditions for the continuous differentiability of the controller were presented.   In the setting prostheses, CLF-QPs were developed that leverage hybrid systems models of locomotion to generate natural heel-toe walking.  Additionally, force interactions between the human and the prosthesis, and the prosthesis and the environment, were utilized directly in the QP to allow for reactive real-time behaviors.  This was realized experimentally in both cases, yielding natural locomotion on powered prostheses on a variety of different terrain types.   Finally, the CLF-QP was also validated on a quadrupedal robot to demonstrate the robust stability of gaits against external disturbances and unknown payloads.

Secondly, reduced-order (template-based) models were studied in the context of dynamic gait generation on legged robots.  In the setting of quadrupedal robots, a computationally tractable robust model predictive controller (RMPC) utilizing single rigid body (SRB) models was developed and validated via extensive numerical simulations and experiments on a quadrupedal robot locomoting on different terrains.  For bipedal robots, we developed a novel reduced order model—the Hybrid Linear Inverted Pendulum (H-LIP)—and characterized the walking behavior of the corresponding step-to-step dynamics of this model; the ability to track global positions, adapt to environmental changes, and place the feet of the biped on constrained footholds, e.g., stepping stones.  Thus, the H-LIP paradigm gives a means to generate a wide range of dynamic gaits in real-time.  These gaits can then be embedded into the full order dynamics of high-dimensional legged robots via the virtual constraint framework, with the result being a CLF-QP tracking outputs that enforce the reduced-order model dynamics. This methodology was verified experimentally on Cassie where a wide range of dynamic locomotion behaviors were demonstrated, both in the lab and outdoors in natural environments, e.g., on uneven terrain. 

Third, in a collaborative effort between Caltech and Virginia Tech, this work investigated a data-driven template model for trajectory planning of dynamic quadrupedal robots. Many state-of-the-art approaches use a reduced-order model, primarily due to computational tractability. The spirit of the trajectory planning approach in this work draws on recent advancements in behavioral systems theory. Here, knowledge of well-known template models was leveraged to construct a data-driven model, yielding an information-rich reduced-order model.  We considered input-output states similar to that of the SRB model and proceeded to develop a data-driven representation of the system, which was then used in a predictive control framework to plan a trajectory for quadrupeds. The optimal trajectory was passed to the low-level and nonlinear model-based controller to be tracked. The experimental results showcase the efficacy of this hierarchical control approach for trotting and walking gaits of a high-dimensional quadrupedal robot on unknown terrains and in the presence of disturbances.

Broader Impact: This work has the potential to enable the ubiquitous use of increasingly sophisticated robots that effectively assist or stand in for humans in situations of extreme danger.   Given the increased emphasis on humanoid robots in industry, the methods from this project can inform the generation of dynamic, robust and adaptable walking gaits that will enable humanoid robots to be deployed in real-world scenarios.  In the context of education, several PhD students at Caltech were supported by this effort, two of whom are going on to tenure-track faculty positions where they plan on continuing to research robotic locomotion and robotic assistive devices.   Numerous undergraduates were involved in the project, many of which have gone on to graduate school.  Finally, the Caltech PI gave numerous invited talks, seminars, plenaries and press interviews where the results of this project were highlighted.


Last Modified: 03/03/2024
Modified by: Aaron D Ames

Image
  • Dynamic locomotion, realized on Cassie through the results of the project, as it walks on uneven terrain. These results were reported in "3-D Underactuated Bipedal Walking via H-LIP Based Gait Synthesis and Stepping Stabilization," Xiaobin Xiong and Aaron Ames, TRO 2022.
    Xiaobin Xiong
    Copyrighted
    Aaron D Ames
    Dynamic Locomotion on Cassie at Caltech
